childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1993-2005

Children born in 1993 arrived one month after the first World Trade Center bombing — a truck packed with explosives in the underground parking garage, designed to topple one tower into the other. It failed. Six people died. The towers stood for eight more years, long enough for this cohort to be sitting in a third-grade classroom when the second attempt succeeded. The bookends of their early life were written at the same address.

The first five years of their childhood unfolded during the peak of the Clinton-era boom — the longest economic expansion in American history, low unemployment, a rising stock market, and a national mood that believed, with decreasing justification, that prosperity was self-sustaining. Their parents had jobs, were buying houses, were saving for college funds that actually seemed adequate. The domestic atmosphere was stable in a way that wouldn't last, and the children absorbing it had no reason to believe it wasn't permanent.

Their early school years — kindergarten through second grade — still belonged to the old world. Classrooms had chalkboards and pull-down maps. The school library used a card catalog. Recess was long. The biggest drama was the playground, where alliances formed and dissolved with the ruthless speed of a five-year-old's attention span. Teachers taught reading through phonics worksheets and the overhead projector. The computer lab, if it existed, had a row of machines along one wall, used mainly for typing games. The pace of education was human-scaled, unhurried, and blissfully unaware of what was about to change.

At eight, September 11 happened. Third grade. This cohort was old enough to understand the basic facts — planes, buildings, fire, death — and young enough that the event was absorbed not as information but as atmosphere. The adults were afraid, and children could tell. School was dismissed early, or it wasn't, but either way the day was different from any day before it. What followed reshaped the remaining years of their childhood: flags on every lawn, troops on the news every night, color-coded threat levels that became as routine as the weather report.

The post-9/11 childhood was qualitatively different from what came before. Airport security became elaborate theater. School lockdown drills, already introduced after Columbine, became more frequent and more serious. The Iraq War began when this cohort was ten, and by the time they finished elementary school, America had been at war for the majority of their conscious lives. War wasn't an event — it was a condition, always there, mentioned at dinner, visible on bumper stickers and yard signs that said "Support Our Troops." The troops were someone's older brother, someone's dad, someone who used to live down the street.

At twelve, Hurricane Katrina drowned New Orleans while the federal government fumbled the response on live television. For this cohort — seventh-graders, old enough to follow the news — it was a lesson in institutional failure as vivid as 9/11 but different in character. The enemy wasn't foreign. The failure wasn't intelligence. The lesson was that the government could simply not show up when its own citizens were dying, and that who got saved and who got left behind had everything to do with race and class and geography. Childhood ended not with a single shock but with the accumulating weight of evidence that the world was more fragile, more unequal, and less protected than anyone had promised.

generational_identity.html:
The Millennial Generation

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996 according to Pew Research, which became the official definition after years of boundary debates. This generation numbers roughly 72 million people in the US, making it the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up. This cohort is in the later part of the range, which means they share some characteristics with older Gen Z while remaining distinctly Millennial.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. This cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. Old enough to watch the towers fall on classroom televisions, young enough for that morning to fundamentally rewire their understanding of safety. They don't remember a pre-9/11 America with any clarity. Airport security, forever wars, color-coded terror alerts—that's just how things were for them.

This generation graduated into the 2008 financial crisis or its long aftermath. This cohort was fifteen when Lehman Brothers collapsed, which meant they watched parents' retirement accounts evaporate, watched neighbors lose homes, learned early that the economy could break and nobody would fix it. By the time they entered the job market, the damage was done. Entry-level positions required five years of experience. Internships were unpaid. The gig economy was the only economy available.

This generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. Millennials are sandwiched between Gen X (who got theirs before everything collapsed) and Gen Z (who never expected to get anything). This generation still believed the American Dream was possible, then watched it become a punchline. That disappointment—believing and then learning they shouldn't have—shapes everything about their worldview.

This generation has been blamed for killing everything from napkins to department stores to the diamond industry. They didn't kill anything—they couldn't afford it. They were too busy paying student loans and splitting rent four ways.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 1993 brought Jurassic Park terrifying everyone with CGI dinosaurs that still hold up thirty years later and Schindler's List making everyone cry in black and white. Spielberg had a year. Groundhog Day came out, which would become shorthand for existential repetition for the next three decades. Sleepless in Seattle proved that Tom Hanks could make rom-coms as well as he made dramas.

Musically, 1993 was peak grunge transitioning into whatever came next. Whitney Houston's 'I Will Always Love You' refused to leave the charts. Nirvana was at its height—Kurt Cobain had a year to live. Dr. Dre had just dropped The Chronic and was changing hip-hop forever. Janet Jackson, Snoop Dogg, and Mariah Carey were all releasing defining work. The '90s had a sound, and 1993 was ground zero.

TV in 1993 gave us The X-Files, which spent nine seasons asking 'what if the government is lying about everything?' and never quite answering, though it turned out the answer was 'yes, obviously.' Late Night with Conan O'Brien premiered—Conan would host that show longer than this cohort has held any job. NYPD Blue pushed the boundaries of network TV and everyone's parents complained about it.

This childhood was peak '90s nostalgia material now. Power Rangers. Rugrats. Boy Meets World. Fresh Prince. Friends started when this cohort was one and ended when they were eleven—they grew up with Ross and Rachel's drama playing in the background like ambient noise. Harry Potter arrived when they were four, and by the time they were teenagers, sorting themselves into Hogwarts houses was unironic identity formation.

The pop culture of this youth was pre-streaming, pre-binging, pre-algorithm. Watching what was on when it was on, or missing it. This taught patience, which is a skill that gets less useful every year as instant gratification becomes standard. They couldn't demand entertainment on command. Entertainment showed up when it felt like it, and they were grateful.

By middle school, TRL was appointment viewing. Britney, Christina, *NSYNC, Backstreet Boys—the late '90s pop explosion was their soundtrack. Having an opinion about Britney versus Christina. Probably still do.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1993 brought Mosaic launching—the first web browser with images, the thing that made the World Wide Web usable for normal people. Most people didn't know what a web browser was. Most people didn't need to. The internet in 1993 was 130 websites, total. It was a research tool for academics and a curiosity for hobbyists. By the time this cohort was old enough to use it, it was eating the world.

Intel released the Pentium processor in 1993. This meant nothing to this cohort at the time—they were learning to hold their head up—but it meant computers would get faster and cheaper throughout their childhood. Moore's Law was working overtime. Every year, technology improved. This felt like progress. It was, in ways that mattered and ways that wouldn't become clear for decades.

Windows 95 launched when this cohort was two, with a Rolling Stones commercial. The first DVDs arrived when they were four. Google was founded in a garage when they were five. The first camera phones appeared in Japan when they were seven. Myspace launched when they were ten. Facebook opened to high schoolers when they were twelve. The iPhone changed everything when they were fourteen. This cohort didn't grow up with smartphones—they watched them conquer civilization in real-time.

This makes them digital natives who remember the analog world clearly. They can use a touchscreen and explain what a rotary phone was. They know what dial-up sounds like. They've waited hours for a single song to download on Napster, only to find it was mislabeled. They've also gotten annoyed when a page takes more than two seconds to load. They contain both patience and impatience.

This generation's relationship with technology is complicated in ways younger generations don't quite understand. They remember when social media didn't exist, when phones were for calling, when being offline was the default state. They've watched screen time colonize every waking moment. They know it's probably bad for them. They can't stop. Nobody can.

Fluent enough to troubleshoot parents' tech problems and wise enough to be suspicious of every new platform. Watching Facebook go from 'fun way to connect with college friends' to 'democracy-eroding misinformation machine.' They've seen this movie before. They're not optimistic about how it ends.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The World Trade Center bombing happened a month before this cohort was born. Six people died, over a thousand injured, and America mostly forgot about it until September 2001, when this cohort was eight years old. They watched the towers fall on live television, probably in a classroom. Their teacher didn't know what to say. Their parents picked them up early. The before and after of that morning divided their childhood.

Pre-9/11 memories are fuzzy but real. This cohort might remember a time when they could walk someone to an airport gate. When shoes didn't come off at security. When the word 'terrorism' wasn't daily vocabulary. That world ended before they turned nine.

Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel when this cohort was four. They probably didn't understand why adults were crying, but they learned that collective grief was something people did together, usually while watching television. They were five during the Lewinsky scandal, which taught them that adults lied about things and then lied about lying.

Columbine happened when this cohort was six. School stopped feeling entirely safe. Lockdown drills became normal. The phrase 'active shooter' entered the vocabulary of childhood. This generation grew up preparing for violence in ways their parents never had to.

This cohort was fifteen during the 2008 financial crisis. They watched parents' retirement accounts evaporate on the evening news. They watched neighbors lose homes. They learned that the economy wasn't stable—it was a house of cards that rich people kept rebuilding with everyone else's money and calling it recovery.

By the time this cohort graduated college around 2015, the world had changed again. Same-sex marriage was legal. Smartphones were universal. Social media had rewired how humans communicated. Donald Trump announced his presidential campaign. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world—early career, still establishing themselves. Plans got postponed. Sense of normal got permanently warped.

This generation has lived through more 'unprecedented' events than most generations see in a lifetime. The only constant has been the certainty that something else unprecedented is coming.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

College graduation around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}}, give or take. The economy had technically recovered from 2008, but 'recovered' meant stable enough for corporations to post record profits while wages stayed flat. Entry-level jobs still demanded three to five years of experience. Unpaid internships were still framed as opportunities rather than exploitation.

This cohort is young enough to have missed the worst of the Great Recession's job market, but old enough to have absorbed its lessons through older siblings and cousins. Watching elder Millennials struggle. Learning that loyalty to employers is a sucker's game. Learning that 'stable career' is an oxymoron. Keeping resumes updated and options open because what choice did they have?

This generation normalized the side hustle because one income stream wasn't enough. Probably driving for Uber, selling things on Etsy, freelancing on Fiverr, or monetizing a hobby just to make ends meet. The gig economy isn't liberation—it's what happens when traditional employment stops paying living wages. Becoming entrepreneurs by necessity, not choice.

Working in offices with ping pong tables and 'unlimited PTO' that nobody takes because the culture punishes rest. Being told to 'bring the whole self to work' by companies that would fire them the moment quarterly earnings dipped. Sitting through mandatory fun and team-building exercises that felt more like hostage situations than morale boosters.

Remote work became normal because of COVID, which hit when this cohort was in their late twenties. Proving they could do their job from anywhere. The reward was employers expecting them to be available everywhere, all the time, on their phone, during dinner, at 10 PM on a Sunday. Work-life balance became work-life blur.

This cohort is in their early thirties now, which means they're old enough to have some career traction but young enough to feel like they're still waiting for things to stabilize. Spoiler: they won't. The stability their parents described isn't coming back. They've adapted to precarity because there was no other option.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

This generation grew up with dating apps as default. Tinder launched when they were twenty—early enough that swiping became natural, late enough that they remember meeting people in person. Experiencing both: the organic connection at a party, through friends, at school, and the algorithmic matching that reduces people to photos and bios. Both feel normal now.

Communication happens primarily through text and DMs. Phone calls feel aggressive—why would someone call without texting first to ask if calling is okay? Voicemails are relics. Entire relationships—flirtation, commitment, conflict, breakup—can happen without ever hearing someone's voice. This is convenient and slightly dystopian, but it's just how things work.

This generation delayed marriage and kids more than any before. Part of it is financial—weddings cost money they don't have, kids cost more, housing is impossible without inherited wealth. Part of it is cultural—the pressure to follow a traditional timeline has loosened, which is freeing but also disorienting. Part of it is practical—wanting stability before adding dependents, but stability keeps taking longer to achieve.

Friendships maintained across distances through group chats and social media. Best friends might live three time zones away. Seeing college roommates once a year but talking to them daily. Geography matters less than it used to, which is good for maintaining connections and bad for building community where one actually lives.

Being in at least one long-distance relationship, made possible by FaceTime and cheap flights. Also experiencing the weird loneliness of being hyperconnected online while feeling isolated in person. Connection and loneliness coexist in ways previous generations didn't have to navigate. Still figuring out how to balance them.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

The dot-com bubble burst when this cohort was eight—abstract at the time, something adults worried about while they worried about third grade. The 2008 financial crisis hit when they were fifteen, which was not abstract at all. Watching adults lose jobs, lose homes, lose faith. The COVID-19 economic collapse came when they were twenty-seven. This generation has watched the economy implode three times before turning thirty-five. This has given them a financial worldview best described as 'perpetually bracing for the next disaster.'

The relationship with money is defined by scarcity that never quite lifts. Graduating with student loan debt that will follow them for decades. Watching housing prices climb 50%, 100%, 200% while wages went up maybe 20%. The math doesn't work. It was never designed to work for them.

Saving obsessively because they've seen how fast stability evaporates. Investing because they don't trust Social Security to exist when they're old, but they don't trust the stock market either, so they hedge, diversify, and hope for the best while expecting the worst. Playing a rigged game because refusing to play means losing by default.

Boomers bought houses on a single income when houses cost twice their annual salary. Gen X got in before prices went parabolic. This generation is competing against investors who buy properties in cash and turn them into short-term rentals, driving up prices they already couldn't afford. Homeownership isn't a milestone anymore—it's a lottery they keep losing.

This generation has been lectured about avocado toast and subscription services by people who bought property for a year's salary and paid off mortgages before turning forty. The generational wealth gap is a chasm. They're on the wrong side of it. Their parents might own their home outright. They're calculating whether they'll ever own one at all.

This generation is redefining financial success out of necessity. It's not a house in the suburbs—it's paying rent in a city where the jobs are while pretending they're not one emergency away from disaster. It's not retiring at sixty-five—it's hoping they can eventually slow down before their body gives out. The American Dream got repriced, and they couldn't afford the markup.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation confuses online engagement with real-world action more than they realize. Great at hashtags, inconsistent at voter turnout. Can mobilize a million retweets for a cause and then not show up to the local election that would actually change policy. Digital activism feels like activism, but feelings aren't legislation.

This generation has been so thoroughly trained to cope with dysfunction that they sometimes forget to fight it. Normalizing burnout as a badge of honor. Accepting that healthcare comes from employers who can fire them at will, that education requires decades of debt, that housing is a luxury. Adapting to a broken system so well that they've stopped demanding it be fixed.

This generation is so steeped in irony that sincerity feels risky. They can't just care about something—they have to care about it with self-aware distance, with acknowledgment of its problems, with protective layers of humor before anyone can mock their earnestness. This makes it hard to advocate for themselves without hedging. It makes asking for what they want feel naive.

This generation's self-deprecation has become its own trap. Joking about being broke, anxious, exhausted—it's relatable, it gets engagement, it builds connection. But it also lets them avoid actually addressing the problems. Laughing about their suffering isn't the same as changing their circumstances. Sometimes the coping mechanism becomes the cage.

This generation is so used to being online that they underestimate how much offline life matters. The friends they text daily aren't the same as friends they see weekly. The communities they belong to on social media aren't the same as communities rooted in physical place and regular presence. They know this intellectually, but the pull of the screen is strong, and real-world connection takes effort the screen doesn't require.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2013-2023): Entering the twenties with Obama in the White House and leaving with a pandemic and a coup attempt. Starting the decade as a fresh college graduate, cautiously optimistic because the economy was supposedly recovering. Ending it questioning whether anything was stable, because nothing was. This was supposed to be the 'figuring it out' decade. It was actually the 'surviving while pretending to figure it out' decade. Changing jobs, changing cities, maybe changing careers entirely. Learning that the life script parents followed didn't apply to them.

The 30s (2023-2033): This decade now. COVID hit early and scrambled whatever plans they had. Making more money than they did at twenty-five, but it still doesn't cover a down payment in any city with jobs. Watching friends buy houses and have kids, and either doing the same or wondering if they ever will. This is the decade where they're supposed to 'have it together,' but having it together looks different than it did for their parents. Building stability on shifting ground, and knowing it could shift again at any moment.

The 40s (2033-2043): Statistically, this will be the peak earning decade. More experience, more authority, more clarity about what they want. Also being sandwiched between aging parents who need care and kids (if they have them) who still need support. Bodies starting to send strongly worded letters about the lifestyle choices of their twenties. This is the decade where they either double down on the path they're on or blow it up and start over. Both are valid. Neither is easy.

The 50s (2043-2053): By this point, having lived through at least four major economic crises, multiple 'once-in-a-generation' disasters that happened every few years, and complete transformations of how humans communicate, work, and relate. Retirement visible on the horizon but probably not reachable at sixty-five. Mentoring people who don't understand why 2008 still haunts them. Catching themselves starting sentences with 'back in my day' and hating themselves for it.

The 60s and beyond (2053+): Traditional retirement isn't guaranteed for this generation. It might be part-time work, phased retirement, or figuring out how to live on whatever Social Security still pays—if it still pays anything. Climate change will have reshaped geography and migration patterns. The technology landscape will be unrecognizable from what they grew up with. Telling younger people about dial-up internet, VHS tapes, and a time when phones couldn't take pictures. They'll look at them like they're describing the Middle Ages. Surviving more change than any generation since the Greatest Generation. That counts for something, even if it doesn't pay the bills.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year. This cohort is part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): More educated, more diverse, and significantly poorer adjusted for age. Gen X entered the workforce when the economy functioned, when degrees paid off predictably, when loyalty was rewarded. This generation entered after it broke. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing. Gen X got affordable college. This generation got crushing debt. Gen X got pensions that actually existed. This generation got 401(k)s and hope.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were this age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. This generation controls 7%. Boomers bought houses on single incomes for twice their annual salary. This generation can't afford one on two incomes when houses cost eight times the median wage. Boomers retired with pensions and Social Security. This generation is hoping those programs survive long enough for them to qualify.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): This generation shares more than they differ. Both grew up with the internet. Both entered adulthood during crises. But this generation remembers life before smartphones, however faintly. Gen Z doesn't. This generation had a childhood largely offline. Gen Z was posting on social media before they could read. This generation is slightly more optimistic, or at least remembers a time when optimism made sense. That memory makes disappointment sharper.

Life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations. This generation has higher rates of mental health challenges than previous generations at the same age. Anxiety and depression are more common. The world they inherited is harder, and it shows in the numbers.

But this generation is also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic injustice than any generation before. They've pushed for equity, destigmatized mental health, and refused to accept what previous generations considered inevitable. This generation inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. That matters.

year_events: World Trade Center bombed for the first time
Jurassic Park broke box office records with CGI dinosaurs
